questions.question: Is there a way to predict the outcome on Election Day even if it's taking a while to announce?

questions.title: What to look out for on Election Day:
questions.description: It'll be a late night and given the high number of mail- in ballots, we'll likely be in for a long wait. Some key states to look out for are Pennsylvania, Florida and Georgia. If Biden does well in these states, it could mean the presidency for him.

imageMetadata.altText: Graphic of the state of Florida with the word "Results" in preparation for Election Day by NewsHour
imageMetadata.resources:
We may not know the results of the election on Election Day and even in the days afterward. In the meantime, follow NewsHour's coverage here: https://www.pbs.org/newshour/tag/vote-2020
And check out EXTRA's Election 2020 classroom resources here: https://www.pbs.org/newshour/extra/tag/super-civics-2020/

questions.title: Generation Z (ages 18-23)
questions.description: Gen Z is very important in this election. 10% of early voters this year have been between the ages of 18-29 and overall turnout for ages 18-23 is expected to be higher than ever before!

imageMetadata.altText: Image of a young person behind plexiglass (due to COVID) voting.

questions.question: Why is Generation Z making such an impact in this election?

choices.answer: Gen Z is less bound to their political parties
Gen Z is more politically engaged
There are more voting-age members of Gen Z this election

questions.title: COVID-19
questions.description: Both candidates have focused their attention on the coronavirus in their last days before the election. President Trump has downplayed the pandemic while former Vice President Biden has made COVID central to his campaign.

imageMetadata.altText: President Trump campaigning in his final days before the 2020 election
imageMetadata.resources:
https://www.pbs.org/newshour/show/what-are-the-2-candidates-strategies-for-the-races-final-days

Let's give it up for the scientists and medical professionals! Read this NewsHour piece to find out how researchers are working round the clock to stop the spread of COVID: ‘"We can’t give up.’ U.S. can still control the spread of COVID-19, experts say: https://www.pbs.org/newshour/health/we-cant-give-up-u-s-can-still-control-the-spread-of-covid-19-experts-say

questions.question: Do you think America's leaders should be showing a more concerned outlook or a more relaxed outlook on the coronavirus?

imageMetadata.altText: Two image of Biden and Trump put together side by side

questions.title: The Electoral College and the Popular Vote
questions.description: The Electoral College is made up of citizens who are designated as official electors for their state. They cast the official vote for president. The popular vote is the voting of citizens leading up to the election through Election Day.

imageMetadata.altText: A person standing in front of a large wall-sized map of the Electoral College.
imageMetadata.resources: Check out EXTRA's lesson plan on the Electoral College here: https://www.pbs.org/newshour/extra/lessons-plans/electoral-college/

questions.resources: Check out EXTRA's lesson plan on the Electoral College here: https://www.pbs.org/newshour/extra/lessons-plans/electoral-college/

questions.question: Five times in history a candidate won the popular vote but lost the election. Is the Electoral College system fair?

choices.answer: No, I think we should get rid of it.
Kind of, we should fix it.
I need to learn more about it first.

imageMetadata.altText: A look at the 2016 election from the popular vote vs the electoral college vote.

questions.question: YOU, as an individual, can change public perceptions about important things that you care about.
